text: No right-thinking person could seriously consider endorsing a campaign entitled ' Team Ched ' . But the toxic swill of social media reaction that the Evans verdict unleashed was frightening to behold . The woman , who had surely been humiliated enough after finding every facet of her sex life pored over in a courtroom , once more faced a welter of sickening abuse . So , too , did women who sought to speak up for her . A passing glimpse of this ghastly public flogging exposed a fundamental hypocrisy . The recent release of the video recording Donald Trump making sexually aggressive comments about women has been condemned the world over .
reworded: No rational individual could genuinely support a campaign named 'Team Ched.' However, the disturbing backlash on social media following the Evans verdict was alarming to witness. The woman, who had already endured humiliation from having every aspect of her sexual history scrutinized in court, was once again subjected to a torrent of vile abuse. Women who dared to advocate for her faced similar hostility. A brief look at this horrific public shaming revealed a deep-seated hypocrisy. The recent emergence of a video showing Donald Trump making sexually aggressive remarks about women has been condemned globally.

text: The tour of projects saw editors and the Governor trekking over several kilometres . It was a show of popularity as residents of the various communities and parts of the Port Harcourt metropolis visited trooped out to hail and catch a glimpse of the man they fondly called " Our Governor " . If democracy is about connecting with the people and lifting their status through development , Wike has etched his name on the boulders of history . He was welcomed everywhere as the man who connected the disconnected people through roads and bridges ; as the leader who comforted the broken-hearted , the pensioners , the artisans , the civil servants and much more as the man who gave hope to the hopeless hoi-polloi .
reworded: The project tour involved editors and the Governor traveling several kilometers together. It was a demonstration of popularity, as residents from various communities and different areas of the Port Harcourt metropolis came out in large numbers to cheer and catch a glimpse of the man they affectionately refer to as "Our Governor." If democracy is about engaging with the populace and enhancing their lives through development, Wike has firmly established his legacy in history. He received a warm welcome everywhere as the leader who united the previously disconnected individuals through infrastructure like roads and bridges; as the one who provided solace to the heartbroken, pensioners, artisans, civil servants, and many others, serving as a beacon of hope for the downtrodden.

text: By learning a skill , and then passing it on to others , Otoyo is not only changing the narrative around disabled people , his work of knitting has also helped him to overcome the trauma of a decade spent fighting under one of the world 's most brutal rebel groups .
reworded: By acquiring a skill and sharing it with others, Otoyo is not only reshaping perceptions of disabled individuals, but his knitting work has also aided him in healing from the trauma of spending a decade in one of the world's most ruthless rebel groups.

text: But do n't forget as the title subtly but unmistakably reminds us , Sudani From Nigeria is all about our fractured identities . In an African nation torn by civil war football is the only passport to a better life for antsy youngsters . Many make it but more fall by the wayside . The African presence in Indian football goes a long way ( remember the Kenyan , Chima Okorie ? ) and in the past two decades , the engine of Kerala football , the sevens soccer , has hummed to the footfalls of African students and youngsters . It is awfully surprising that it took all this while to have a peep into that dark secret of what makes them football refugees .
reworded: However, let's not overlook what the title subtly yet clearly indicates: Sudani From Nigeria focuses on our fragmented identities. In a war-torn African country, football serves as the sole means for restless youth to aspire for a better future. While some succeed, many others are left behind. The presence of Africans in Indian football has a rich history (remember the Kenyan, Chima Okorie?) and over the last twenty years, the heartbeat of Kerala football, particularly in seven-a-side matches, has resonated with the footsteps of African students and youth. It's quite astonishing that it has taken this long to gain insight into the hidden realities of what turns them into football refugees.

text: Another fond memory I cherish was the day he and I were coming from the mosque when two men approached him and importuned him to give them money . They said they had n't eaten all day . My dad was the kindest human being I ever know . He would give his last penny to people in need . So he gave the men all the money he had on him . " I do n't have a lot with me now , but I am a salary earner and the month will end in a few days . You need this more than I do , " he said .
reworded: One cherished memory I hold dear is the day my father and I were leaving the mosque when two men approached him, pleading for money. They claimed they hadn’t eaten all day. My dad was the kindest person I ever knew, always willing to give his last penny to those in need. So, he handed the men all the cash he had on him. “I don’t have much right now, but I receive a salary, and the month will end soon. You need this more than I do,” he told them.

text: King Wenceslas is probably standing on an elevated balcony of his residence when there arose a mild wind , which probably brought with it snowflakes . At a distance he was able to see a man in dire need . A peasant . A farmer or woodcutter , trying to gather some logs to take to his lackluster cottage , with the hope of cooking a meal . The benevolent King is deeply moved by this sight . He inquires of his young servant , and is told the man has come down from near the mountains . Today in a self righteous society , how many would even come out to their balcony , even in fine tropical weather ? How would they respond to the sight of such hopeless despair ?
reworded: King Wenceslas is likely standing on an elevated balcony of his palace when a gentle breeze brings with it some snowflakes. From his vantage point, he notices a man in desperate need—a peasant, possibly a farmer or woodcutter, struggling to gather logs to take back to his modest cottage in hopes of preparing a meal. The compassionate King is profoundly touched by this scene. He asks his young servant about the man, who informs him that the man has descended from the nearby mountains. In today's self-righteous society, how many would even step out onto their balcony, even in pleasant tropical weather? How would they react to witnessing such hopelessness?

text: Trump seeks $25 billion for border wall , offers ' Dreamer ' citizenship <h> President Donald Trump on Wednesday previewed his outline for an immigration bill that he will promote next week , saying he wants $25 billion ( 17.6 billion pounds ) to build a border wall and is open to granting citizenship to illegal immigrants who were brought to the United States as children .
reworded: President Donald Trump on Wednesday unveiled his proposal for an immigration bill that he plans to advocate for next week. He stated that he is requesting $25 billion (£17.6 billion) to construct a border wall and is willing to consider offering citizenship to undocumented immigrants who were brought to the United States as children.

text: As a child , I have always been told to give to those who are in need . I have been raised up to believe that if I do n't give to the needy , I will find my way to hell . Due to these teachings that has been imbued in me , I have been generally been sympathetic to the needy . After all it is said in the Holy Scriptures that " there is blessing in giving than receiving " . Growing up , I have however disabused my mind of this notion . I am just tired of seeing a familiar face beg on the street for far too long , I am tired of giving money to a beggar who asks me for money today and yet shamefully ask me for help again when he or she meets me on the next day .
reworded: As a child, I was always taught to help those in need. I grew up believing that failing to support the less fortunate would lead me to hell. These teachings have instilled in me a general compassion for those who are struggling. After all, the Holy Scriptures say that "there is more blessing in giving than receiving." However, as I matured, I began to rethink this belief. I’ve grown weary of seeing familiar faces begging on the streets for too long. I’m tired of giving money to a beggar who asks for help today and then shamefully approaches me again the next day.

text: I 'm sorry to say that the average Nigerian woman is so much afraid of losing the grounds she has gained . This is unlike the men , who , when they climb up , leave the ladder for other men to climb same ladder to come and meet them there . The average Nigerian woman climbs the ladder and uses her left foot to push the ladder down . It 's unfortunate . You know why ? She lacks confidence in herself . Only a few women leaders ever think that once they are up there , no matter how they open doors for others , no other woman will come bring them down . That is the reason why a Nigerian woman today will have so much and will still have friends dying of lack .
reworded: I regret to say that the typical Nigerian woman is often very fearful of losing her hard-won achievements. In contrast, men tend to ascend the ladder and then allow others to climb up to join them. The average Nigerian woman, however, tends to pull the ladder up behind her after she climbs. It’s a sad situation. Why is this the case? She lacks self-confidence. Only a small number of women leaders believe that once they reach a certain level, they can open doors for others without fearing that those women will undermine them. This is why many Nigerian women may have so much, yet still see their friends struggling and lacking basic necessities.

text: Cecil Duddley Mends who is the CEO of Duddleys Expressions , a modern state of the art Fashion Couture in Ghana that focuses mainly on fashion shows in Africa and Europe did n't only win the Fashion Designer of the year award because of his immense progress in Ghana 's Fashion , but was also honored because he gave people hope from the hopelessness by training more than 1,000 people for free that can put food on their tables .
reworded: Cecil Duddley Mends, the CEO of Duddleys Expressions, a cutting-edge Fashion Couture brand in Ghana that primarily emphasizes fashion shows in Africa and Europe, not only received the Fashion Designer of the Year award due to his significant advancements in Ghana's fashion scene, but he was also recognized for instilling hope in those facing despair by providing free training to over 1,000 individuals, enabling them to support themselves.

text: Islamic philosophy has dealt at length with the study of inherent mental qualities and inclinations among human beings with special reference to moral virtue . Some human beings are totally inclined to the pursuit of virtue , and are consumed with desire for knowledge of the Divine World , known as m ' arifat , or gnosis . Others tend to be carried away by the things and pleasures of the world . There is a middle , order of persons who have inclination to gnosis , and also have aptitude for worldly , affairs . This last category is described by Imam Razi , writing in the 12th century , as " the people of the right hand or the balanced people " , and to such persons , control over the affairs of their fellowmen rightly belongs . The task is never easy ; mere goodness is no guarantee for success . Possession of all the virtues alone is not sufficient . There must be inspiration from a higher source . The element of marifat provides the necessary directions , by holding the attention to the Divine light . No leader of any community who has gained success in managing its affairs and certainly no leader who led his people out of bondage , or saved them from the threat of hopeless submergence under a majority , hostile to them , can ever have done so by the exercise of mere human intelligence , or brain power or character .
reworded: Islamic philosophy has extensively explored the intrinsic mental traits and tendencies of humans, particularly in relation to moral virtue. Some individuals are deeply driven by the quest for virtue and possess a strong yearning for knowledge of the Divine Realm, referred to as m'arifat or gnosis. Conversely, others may become distracted by worldly pleasures and material pursuits. There exists a middle group of individuals who are inclined towards gnosis while also being adept in worldly matters. Imam Razi, writing in the 12th century, characterizes this group as "the people of the right hand or the balanced people," who are rightly entrusted with the governance of their communities. However, this responsibility is challenging; simply being good does not guarantee success. Merely possessing virtues is insufficient; there must be inspiration from a higher power. The aspect of marifat offers essential guidance by directing attention towards the Divine light. No successful leader of a community, especially one who has liberated their people from oppression or safeguarded them from the threat of a hostile majority, could have achieved this solely through human intellect, reasoning, or character.

text: We can not talk about poverty in this nation without coming to grips with how utterly broken our housing system is for America 's poor . More than 50 percent of poor families in the U.S. spend at least half their income on housing . Of the families who qualify for housing assistance , only 1 on 4 receives it . Is it any wonder , then , that they struggle to keep roofs over their heads or food on their tables -- let alone find a path to the middle class ?
reworded: We cannot discuss poverty in this country without acknowledging the severe dysfunction of our housing system for the impoverished. Over half of low-income families in the U.S. allocate at least 50% of their income to housing costs. Among those eligible for housing assistance, only 25% actually receive it. Is it any surprise, then, that they find it challenging to maintain stable housing or provide food for their families, much less achieve upward mobility into the middle class?

text: People in Africa are deceived into believing that the West is the haven for prosperity , an idea drummed into them from an early age by a continent reliant on remittances from overseas workers . Borrowing Thomas Hobbes ' words , I describe the life of many if not most African immigrants in the industrialized world simply as ' solitary , poor , nasty , brutish and short ' .
reworded: Many individuals in Africa are misled into thinking that the West is a land of opportunity, a notion instilled in them from a young age by a continent dependent on remittances from workers abroad. To borrow the words of Thomas Hobbes, I would characterize the existence of many, if not most, African immigrants in developed countries as 'isolated, impoverished, harsh, brutal, and fleeting.'

text: BISHOPS having a meal with poor families on the eve of the International Eucharistic Congress ( IEC ) was meaningful symbol . text: Dinu had developed a theme of life . It was , " The circumstances of your life do n't and should n't describe or dictate the quality of your personality . " Dinu did n't let these new and trying circumstances change any aspect of her character or her life . Though she herself was sick and in pain , she still took time to visit if a friend or relative was sick . Though she was in need , she was always there to help others when needed . She always had time to talk to her friends . Dinu 's Bible theme verse was Col 4:2 " Continue earnestly in prayer , being vigilant in it with thanksgiving . "
reworded: Dinu had embraced a philosophy about life: "The circumstances you face should not define or dictate the quality of your character." Despite the challenging situations she encountered, Dinu refused to let them alter any part of her personality or her life. Even while dealing with her own illness and discomfort, she made it a point to visit friends or relatives who were unwell. Although she had her own needs, she was always ready to assist others in times of need. She consistently made time to converse with her friends. Dinu's guiding Bible verse was Colossians 4:2: "Continue steadfastly in prayer, being watchful in it with thanksgiving."

text: When we talk about the freedom it is essential to remember the valiant war heroes who fought to save our country from L. T. T. E. terrorism throughout 30 years . They sacrificed their lives . They lost their limbs . They became disabled and their families suffered heavily . Economy was ruined . About 100,000 people including civilians lost their lives . Thousands became disabled . Are the people who lost their lives in the 30 years long war were losers ? Are those who saved their lives are winners ? I believe that we , who saved our lives from that tragedy , should remember the lessons we learnt .
reworded: When discussing freedom, it's crucial to honor the brave soldiers who dedicated their lives to protecting our nation from L.T.T.E. terrorism over three decades. They made tremendous sacrifices, losing their lives, limbs, and enduring disabilities, while their families faced immense hardships. The economy suffered greatly, and approximately 100,000 individuals, including civilians, lost their lives, with thousands more becoming disabled. Should we consider those who perished in this 30-year conflict as failures? And do we label those who survived as victors? I believe that we, who emerged from that tragedy, must reflect on the lessons we learned.

text: Six-year-old Sandra moved to the capital city , Abuja with her family . She has four siblings and her father is a taxi driver , while her mother fries and sells akara outside the uncompleted building they live in . Her father had learned that there was money in the thriving taxi business in the capital city and they had left their village in search of greener pastures , only that it did not seem so green here , in the decrepit looking building where she and her siblings are left vulnerable each day as their parents step out the door to make a living .
reworded: Six-year-old Sandra relocated to the capital city, Abuja, with her family. She has four siblings, and her father works as a taxi driver, while her mother prepares and sells akara outside the unfinished building where they reside. Her father discovered that the taxi business in the capital was lucrative, prompting them to leave their village in pursuit of better opportunities. However, it doesn’t appear to be as promising in their rundown building, where she and her siblings are left vulnerable each day as their parents go out to earn a living.

text: And like temporary refugees , they became the problem of the Izon sons and daughters in the corridors of government in Asaba , the delta state capital . And why ca n't they engage in some other forms of businesses that are legal and stress free ?
reworded: Like temporary refugees, they became a concern for the Izon sons and daughters within the government corridors in Asaba, the capital of Delta State. For three consecutive days, they pleaded for transport fares to return to their homes in Benue State. When questioned about their desire to go back to Benue despite the severe disruption caused by the Illicit Law, they were also asked why they couldn't pursue other legal and less stressful business opportunities.

text: The school is doing fine . It has the total number of 19 teaching staff , 2 administrative staff , 1 librarian and 2 supportive staff . The scholarship programme was introduced to rescue children from our target i.e. children from poor families , those at risk of losing parental care and those who have lost their parents . reworded: The school is doing well. It has a total of 19 teachers, 2 administrative personnel, 1 librarian, and 2 support staff members. There are 392 students enrolled, with 97 coming from SOS Children’s Village, 100 from the scholarship program, and the remainder from the local community. The scholarship program was established to assist children from our target demographic—those from low-income families, those at risk of losing parental care, and those who have lost their parents. The organization supplies them with all necessary school materials, including uniforms and exercise books.

text: Muniba 's was n't an easy journey and yet she challenged norms and mindset and changed her adversity to an opportunity . In December last year she was named Pakistan 's first female national goodwill ambassador for gender equality and women 's empowerment by the UN and she is an active speaker for the rights of disabled people in Pakistan . In fact , she was also the first wheel chair bound model to campaign for Toni & Guy Pakistan and is also brand ambassador for The Body Shop Pakistan . But above all , Muniba is a loving mother fulfilling all her responsibilities to tee . Clearly , there is no stopping her .
reworded: Muniba's journey has been far from easy, yet she defied societal norms and transformed her challenges into opportunities. Last December, she was appointed by the UN as Pakistan's first female national goodwill ambassador for gender equality and women's empowerment. She actively advocates for the rights of disabled individuals in Pakistan. Notably, she was the first wheelchair-bound model to represent Toni & Guy Pakistan and serves as the brand ambassador for The Body Shop Pakistan. Above all, Muniba is a devoted mother, diligently fulfilling her responsibilities. Clearly, nothing can hold her back.

reworded: Dodgeballs were soaring quickly and forcefully at Morningside College today during the 5th Annual Attack of the Killer Dodgeball Tournament fundraiser. text: What is your advice to Nigerian women ? My advice to women is that they should step forward and be bold , as stated in the UN declaration . I want women to be encouraged . reworded: What advice would you give to Nigerian women? I encourage women to take initiative and be courageous, as highlighted in the UN declaration. I want to inspire women to find something they can champion. It's not solely about finances; it’s about the community around you. Begin with your local area, and you will reach your desired goals.

text: In any nation where people with disabilities are given little help by both the community and the government and are therefore unemployable and living with few options , for me to judge the way that they have found to survive , which is often begging , is a luxury for which I , who have never been truly hungry or in need , should be very , very cautious with .
reworded: In any country where individuals with disabilities receive minimal support from both the community and the government, rendering them unemployable and with limited choices, I believe it is a privilege for someone like me—who has never experienced true hunger or hardship—to judge the means they resort to for survival, which often includes begging. I should approach this judgment with great caution.

reworded: The School for the Blind, Deaf, and Dumb in Isulo, Anambra State, features several impressive buildings but faces significant challenges due to inadequate facilities for the children's special educational needs. text: I end this essay with questions for government and society . Can there ever be a place for humour in the life of the disabled ? Are there disabled friendly environments in Nigeria ? Do we have barrier-free restaurants and alternative routes for the disabled ? How do the disabled manage to deal with self confidence ? How do they feel when they have to ask for help ? Are people with disability lawless ? Do government and society owe people with disability anything ? Abah wrote from Port Harcourt .
reworded: I conclude this essay with some questions directed at both the government and society. Is there a place for humor in the lives of individuals with disabilities? Are there environments in Nigeria that are accommodating for the disabled? Do we have restaurants that are accessible and alternative pathways for those with disabilities? How do individuals with disabilities maintain their self-confidence? What emotions do they experience when they need to ask for assistance? Are people with disabilities considered to be lawless? Do the government and society have any obligations towards individuals with disabilities? Abah wrote this from Port Harcourt.

text: These poor families face double-digit inflation this year thanks to food , electricity and transport hikes . Gordhan 's ' real ' ( after-inflation ) cuts by several percent to welfare grants will lower the incomes of 16.5 million recipients ( out of the country 's population of 55 million ) . They will struggle to find more holes in their frayed belts to tighten them up , given that 63 per cent of South Africans -- mostly women -- already live below the poverty line .
reworded: These struggling families are grappling with double-digit inflation this year due to increases in food, electricity, and transportation costs. Gordhan's "real" cuts to welfare grants, which amount to several percentage points after accounting for inflation, will reduce the incomes of 16.5 million beneficiaries out of the nation's 55 million population. With 63 percent of South Africans—predominantly women—already living below the poverty line, they will find it increasingly difficult to tighten their already strained budgets.

text: " Initially I wanted the charity to be about helping Jamaicans on a whole , but I figured I would start where people are the worst off , which I believe are the homeless people , because they literally have nothing , but now since I have the other people on board , it is going to be more widely spread to education and general poverty , " she said .
reworded: "At first, I envisioned the charity as a way to assist Jamaicans as a whole, but I realized it would be more effective to focus on those who are in the most dire situations, specifically the homeless, as they truly have nothing. However, now that I have others involved, our efforts will expand to include education and general poverty," she stated.

text: " If I die ... I know there is a day that I will die , when that day reaches then I would like to be remembered for helping many children from the poor families to have access to modern and quality education ... that is why I have been moving up and down to ensure that we have good schools that will provide an opportunity for our youth to get a good education ... in these schools we do have Germany teachers and others ( volunteers ) from other developed world so as to ensure quality education is provided to our children , " he said .
reworded: "If I pass away... I am aware that there will come a day when I will no longer be here. When that time arrives, I hope to be remembered for my efforts in helping numerous children from underprivileged families gain access to modern and quality education. This is why I have been tirelessly working to establish good schools that will provide our youth with the opportunity for a solid education. In these schools, we have German teachers and other volunteers from developed countries to ensure that our children receive a high standard of education," he stated.

Witnessing became the witness of tears .
reworded: The approaching sound of bulldozers, the sight of bodies wrapped in white Eritrean shawls (suria) praying beside me, and the stark contrast between silent hopes for peace and the harsh reality of destruction and despair overwhelmed any words that attempted to capture the scene. text: But it 's really not that incredible any more , is it ? text: The hundreds of families that have gathered at the enormous NRG centre in the southern outskirts of Houston may have a roof over their heads , but their plight is similar to those who left the Middle East for Europe . They are refugees—individuals who have lost their homes, belongings, and often their means of making a living.

text: The conservative-majority , nine-member court has never heard arguments on the legal merits of the travel ban or any other major Trump immigration policy , including his move to rescind protections for young immigrants sometimes called Dreamers brought into the United States illegally as children .
reworded: The court, which has a conservative majority and consists of nine justices, has yet to consider the legal aspects of the travel ban or any significant immigration policies from Trump, including his decision to eliminate protections for young immigrants, often referred to as Dreamers, who were brought to the United States illegally as children.

text: Akka was the epitome of simplicity often dressed in white . She shunned jewellery , wearing only a simple pair of ear studs . Her adornment was her beautiful smile , which radiated her goodness and inner peace . Akka 's compassion and caring knew no bounds . She would reach out to those in need , those who were hurting , and was able to comfort , encourage and heal.She was always ready to lend a helping hand , paying the school fees of less affluent students at Methodist College , providing a regular supply of dry rations to families who were struggling economically , all without publicity or fanfare.The daily maid who helped her with cleaning , tearfully told me that akka had given her Rs. 1000 to buy Christmas gifts for her two little boys just before she was admitted to hospital in December .
reworded: Akka embodied simplicity, often seen in white attire. She avoided jewelry, opting for just a modest pair of ear studs. Her true ornamentation was her radiant smile, which reflected her kindness and inner tranquility. Akka's compassion was limitless; she consistently reached out to those in distress, offering comfort, encouragement, and healing. Always willing to help, she paid the school fees for less fortunate students at Methodist College and regularly provided dry rations to families in economic hardship, all without seeking recognition. The daily maid who assisted her with cleaning shared tearfully that Akka had given her Rs. 1000 to buy Christmas gifts for her two young sons just before she was hospitalized in December.

text: " The villages around our campus are not very developed . There is hardly any facility available for youths from poor families . reworded: "The villages surrounding our campus are not well-developed, and there are very few resources available for young people from low-income families. As a Jesuit institution, our primary goal is to achieve academic excellence. However, our schools have also significantly contributed to enhancing the educational environment in the areas around them," stated Vice-Chancellor Father Felix Raj.

text: If most good things begin in the home , so must the life-or-death battle relating to global warming . Across the world , creative and innovative architects have developed more affordable and eco-friendly ways of building houses . Sri Lanka 's Housing and Construction Minister Sajith Premadasa , continuing the good work his father started , has launched hundreds of projects , mainly in rural areas , to provide houses with deeds and small plots of land to homeless people . Social analysts see this as the first major step towards restoring the dignity of these poverty-stricken families , so that they could earn their living and rise from the second-class citizenship of living on the dole .
reworded: If many positive changes start at home, then the critical fight against global warming must also begin there. Around the globe, inventive and resourceful architects are creating more cost-effective and environmentally friendly building methods. In Sri Lanka, Housing and Construction Minister Sajith Premadasa is carrying on his father's legacy by initiating hundreds of projects, primarily in rural regions, to provide housing with property deeds and small land parcels to those without homes. Social analysts view this as a significant initial step towards restoring dignity to these impoverished families, enabling them to support themselves and escape the stigma of relying on welfare.

text: The PCD act has the provision that a substitute decision-maker be named on your behalf if you have not previously formulated one . Do you want that decision to be put in the hands of a spouse , child or even parent , in the case of a disabled child , who may not see the value of a world of imperfection ? Someone who is estranged or who does not know your wishes ? Someone acting because they see you as a burden to them or society ?
reworded: The PCD act includes a provision that allows for a substitute decision-maker to be appointed on your behalf if you haven't designated one beforehand. Would you prefer that this responsibility falls to a spouse, child, or even a parent, particularly in the case of a disabled child who might not appreciate the value of an imperfect world? What if this person is estranged or unaware of your desires? Or perhaps they might act out of a sense that you are a burden to them or to society?

text: SM Hassan Siddiquee Pope Francis has proclaimed Mother Teresa of Kolkata a saint , hailing her as the personification of maternal love and a powerful advocate for the poor . Queen Sofia of Spain and some 1,500 homeless people also looked on as Pope Francis described Saint Teresa 's work in the slums of the Indian Metropolis as " eloquent witness to God 's closeness to the poorest of the poor . " There has been debates and controversies over Saint Teresa 's legacy since she ...
reworded: SM Hassan Siddiquee Pope Francis has declared Mother Teresa of Kolkata a saint, celebrating her as the embodiment of maternal love and a strong advocate for the impoverished. Queen Sofia of Spain and around 1,500 homeless individuals witnessed as Pope Francis referred to Saint Teresa's efforts in the slums of the Indian metropolis as an "eloquent witness to God's closeness to the poorest of the poor." Since then, there have been discussions and controversies surrounding Saint Teresa's legacy.

text: By Fr Ron RolheiserWhenever we have been at our best , as Christians , we have opened our churches as sanctuaries to the poor and the endangered . We have a long , proud history wherein refugees , homeless persons , immigrants facing deportation , and others who are endangered , have taken shelter inside our churches . If we believe what Jesus tells us about the Last Judgment in the twentyfifth chapter of Matthew 's Gospel , this should serve us well when we stand before God at the end .
reworded: By Fr. Ron Rolheiser, whenever we have truly excelled as Christians, we have welcomed the poor and vulnerable into our churches as safe havens. Our history is rich and proud, filled with instances where refugees, the homeless, immigrants facing deportation, and others in peril have found refuge within our walls. If we take to heart what Jesus teaches about the Last Judgment in the twenty-fifth chapter of Matthew's Gospel, this understanding will serve us well when we stand before God in the end.

text: Defend your dignity as human beings and children of God . Do not allow the rich and powerful , who are rich because you are poor , to divide you . They have light and water in their high fenced houses not because they are Muslims or Christians or that they are from this or that or the other tribe but simply because they are rich . You are poor , homeless , have no road , no water , and your children are sick and illiterate , not because you are Christian or Muslim or from this tribe or the other , but simply because you are poor . You and your children vote , but their children do not vote because they are abroad . Your children beg and die on the streets while their children are abroad fraternizing with those they call unbelievers . They give you a fake religion that enslaves you while they give their own children the religion of education that will liberate them and make them rule over you .
reworded: Stand firm in your dignity as human beings and children of God. Do not let the wealthy and powerful, who thrive on your poverty, create divisions among you. They enjoy luxuries like light and water in their gated homes not due to their faith as Muslims or Christians or their tribal affiliations, but simply because they possess wealth. Your poverty, homelessness, lack of infrastructure, and the suffering and illiteracy of your children are not a result of your religion or tribe, but solely because you are impoverished. While you and your children cast votes, their children do not participate in elections because they are living abroad. Your children struggle and perish on the streets while theirs mingle with those they label as unbelievers overseas. They impose a false religion on you that keeps you enslaved, while they provide their own children with an education that empowers them to dominate over you.

text: These are all examples close to home , but they are not unique , or in isolation . There are millions of maids out there who face the same ordeal faced by the maids I have personally come into contact with . These women are victims of their circumstances . Born in poor families , they are doomed to carry the legacy of their poverty all the way through to the furthest of their posterity .
reworded: These examples are familiar and not isolated incidents. There are countless maids who endure the same struggles as those I have encountered personally. These women are victims of their situations. Coming from impoverished families, they are destined to inherit the burden of poverty that will affect generations to come.

reworded: Cosatu's deputy president Zingiswa Losi will collaborate with Christine Olivier, her counterpart at the National Union of Metalworkers of SA, along with representatives from the ANC Women’s League and Sadtu, to distribute sanitary towels to 345 disadvantaged and impoverished girl students at Tyongwana Senior Primary School, located near Port St Johns in the Eastern Cape.

text: In the context of Bangladesh the existence of a place like the CRP is nothing short of miraculous . In contrast to most of the country , the disabled here are n't patronised , rather , they are given the help that they need , according to their individual needs and more importantly , instilled with the confidence that they can have a productive life again in spite of their injuries . The disabled , and we as a society , owe much to the heroic work being done by the men and women at the CRP and their partners .
reworded: In Bangladesh, the presence of an institution like the CRP is truly remarkable. Unlike many other places in the country, individuals with disabilities here are not treated with condescension; instead, they receive tailored support according to their specific needs. More importantly, they are empowered with the belief that they can lead fulfilling lives again, despite their challenges. The remarkable efforts of the dedicated staff at the CRP and their collaborators have greatly benefited both the disabled individuals and society as a whole.

text: The first point worth mentioning is low levels of living , characterized by low incomes , inequality , poor health and inadequate education . In developing countries , the levels of living tend to be very low for the vast majority of people . These low levels of living are manifested quantitatively and qualitatively in the form of low life and work expectancies , high infant mortality rate and in many cases a general sense of malaise and hopelessness .
reworded: The initial point to highlight is the low standards of living, which are marked by low incomes, inequality, poor health, and insufficient education. In developing nations, the majority of the population experiences very low living conditions. These low standards are evident both quantitatively and qualitatively, reflected in short life and work expectancies, a high infant mortality rate, and often a pervasive sense of discontent and despair.

text: In the city of Hyderabad , ' Walls of Kindness ' appeared over the weekend . text: Needless to say , whatever is the level of one 's disability , they face tenacious stigma and social exclusion in addition to their persistent physical or mental challenges . If life is hard for differently-abled adults , we can only imagine what it could be like for children . Their parents become tired , frustrated , and hopeless . Most of them lack financial and other resources to cope with the situation . It is almost inconceivable how burdened and helpless they feel , and therefore resort to a resigned acceptance of fate .
reworded: It goes without saying that regardless of the severity of an individual's disability, they encounter persistent stigma and social isolation alongside their ongoing physical or mental difficulties. If life is challenging for adults with disabilities, we can only imagine the struggles faced by children. Their parents often feel exhausted, frustrated, and hopeless. Many lack the financial and other resources necessary to manage the situation. It is almost unimaginable how overwhelmed and powerless they feel, leading them to a resigned acceptance of their circumstances.

reworded: In Jamaica, it is sadly true that the police continue to have a difficult relationship with the communities they aim to serve. Each day, the brave men and women of the JCF face the daunting task of safeguarding the innocent and vulnerable from those who show little respect for the sanctity of human life.

text: After being hit by a burst of pellets in his face , twenty-year-old Omar Altaf of Islamabad from South Kashmir is disabled forever . He has lost the vision in his left eye while his right eye has faint sight . His blaring eyes are witness to the mayhem he saw on roads when Indian forces fired pellets .
reworded: After being struck in the face by a barrage of pellets, twenty-year-old Omar Altaf from Islamabad, originally from South Kashmir, is permanently disabled. He has lost vision in his left eye, while his right eye has only limited sight. His wide-open eyes bear witness to the chaos he experienced on the streets when Indian forces unleashed the pellets.

text: When she delivered her Nobel lecture , two decades after being awarded the prize , she mentioned the " great sufferings " addressed in Buddhist theology and dwelt on two she had come to know intimately : " To be parted from those one loves and to be forced to live in propinquity with those one does not love . " She continued : " I thought of prisoners and refugees , of migrant workers and victims of human trafficking , of that great mass of the uprooted of the Earth who have been torn away from their homes , parted from families and friends , forced to live out their lives among strangers who are not always welcoming . "
reworded: When she gave her Nobel lecture, two decades after receiving the award, she spoke about the "great sufferings" highlighted in Buddhist teachings and focused on two that she had come to understand deeply: "Being separated from loved ones and having to live closely with those one does not love." She added, "I thought of prisoners and refugees, migrant workers and victims of human trafficking, and that vast number of displaced individuals around the world who have been uprooted from their homes, separated from family and friends, and compelled to navigate life among strangers who are not always welcoming."

reworded: Free school meals support the most disadvantaged. Additionally, we have various systems in place for those who genuinely need financial assistance—I'm referring to those who truly require help, not those who are trying to exploit the system by having other struggling families cover their child's meals.

text: Poverty . Forty-seven million people rely on food stamps . Thirty-eight million households have nothing saved for retirement . Some 1.2 million children are homeless . An estimated 58,000 veterans live on the streets each night . These facts are a national disgrace . America 's massive , grinding poverty is eating away at our strength . What kind of a " superpower " allows a million children to fend for themselves on the street ?
reworded: Poverty is a significant issue. Forty-seven million individuals depend on food assistance. Thirty-eight million families have no savings for retirement. Approximately 1.2 million children are without homes. An estimated 58,000 veterans spend each night on the streets. These statistics represent a national shame. The extensive and persistent poverty in America is undermining our strength. What kind of "superpower" permits a million children to survive alone on the streets?

text: In the last four decades , tribal society has passed through the most torturous , bloody , destructive , divisive and increasingly brutalising phases . The sons and daughters of these dark times saw nothing except barbarities , hopelessness and helplessness . The children of jihad from the war zone had no window of opportunity or expression . As they saw a most handsome young man -- an aspiring model with fascinating attire and alluring photo sessions -- being cold-bloodedly murdered , they simply could not take it anymore and thronged to public spaces with a white flag in their hands . Suddenly , we see a Pashtun civil rights ' spring emerging from the death-fields of FATA .
reworded: Over the past forty years, tribal society has endured some of the most agonizing, violent, destructive, and divisive periods, which have increasingly led to brutality. The youth born during these grim times have witnessed nothing but atrocities, despair, and powerlessness. The children raised in the conflict zones of jihad found themselves without any opportunities for expression. When they witnessed the shocking murder of a striking young man—a hopeful model dressed in captivating outfits and engaged in alluring photo shoots—they reached a breaking point and took to the streets holding white flags. In that moment, a Pashtun civil rights movement began to rise from the devastated lands of FATA.

text: When Prophet Elijah the Tishbite was so frustrated and hopeless that contemplated suicide and told God to kill him , the first thing God did was to solve his immediate need by giving him food . He gave him food again until he ate and his heart was settled and thought of suicide no more .
reworded: When Prophet Elijah the Tishbite found himself in such deep frustration and hopelessness that he wished for death and asked God to take his life, God's initial response was to address his immediate need by providing him with food. He continued to feed Elijah until he was nourished, which brought peace to his heart and removed any thoughts of suicide.
